author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Declaration Upon Walking In the Door
description: What would a women’s week be without Robyn Weintraub?
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I have really been savoring this week, solvers. I don’t mean to ruffle any genderfeathers; I just happen to extremely dig every one of the constructors we’ve seen so far. I am sure that you were all looking for this one yesterday, as Fridays are Robyn Weintraub’s domain, but have no fear: Here she is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: When Will We Be Ready for a President Warren?
description: Michelle Cottle joins readers in mourning the end of a dream for 2021.
content: “Winning the presidency is not merely — or even largely — a question of merit,” writes Michelle Cottle in her column, “Elizabeth Warren Had a Good Run. Maybe Next Time, Ladies.” “It’s hard for any candidate to get the formula right. For women, it is harder because of a host of unconscious biases.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Troy Collings, 33, Who Took Travelers Into North Korea, Dies
description: His company takes travelers to “destinations your mother would rather you stay away from.” One client was Otto Warmbier, who was imprisoned and fell into a coma.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — Troy Collings, whose tour-guide company specialized in taking young budget travelers to forbidding places like North Korea, where one of his clients, the American Otto F. Warmbier, was imprisoned and fell into a coma, died last week, the company said on Friday. He was 33.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 7, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 7, 2020.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the hockey player Mika Zibanejad’s five-goal game for the Rangers misstated the status of his contract. He is in the third of its five years, not the second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kit Dillon
title: What to Bring on Vacation if You Want to Learn How to Surf
description: The surf school will provide the board and a wet suit if necessary, but here are a few things to keep yourself safe and comfortable while still able to move around freely.
content: Compared to other sports, surfing requires less gear to get started. But if you are planning to take lessons on your next beach vacation, you will want to pack a few things to keep yourself safe and comfortable while still being able to move freely. No need to buy a wet suit — along with a board, the surf school will provide one if it’s necessary — but consider bringing the following items. And don’t forget a tube of good reef-safe sunscreen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: No Handshakes, No New Citizens: Coronavirus Halts Danish Naturalizations
description: The government in Denmark has asked mayors to suspend naturalization ceremonies, which since a law passed in 2018 require a mandatory handshake.
content: LONDON — The mayor of a city in Eastern Denmark was preparing to hold a citizenship ceremony when he received a call from the country’s immigration and integration ministry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rethinking the Primary System
description: Readers react to an editorial in favor of ranked-choice voting and offer their own ideas for a better way to elect a president.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Yankees’ Aaron Judge Is Out for Opening Day With Rib Fracture
description: After months of pain, Judge said on Friday that he had a stress fracture that may take months to heal.
content: TAMPA, Fla. — The good news: The source of the mysterious pain in Aaron Judge’s shoulder and chest has finally been identified. He has a stress fracture in his uppermost right rib. The bad news: He has a stress fracture in his uppermost right rib that will keep him out of the Yankees lineup on opening day, and surgery hasn’t been ruled out yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: A Deaf-Blind Dishwasher Achieves His Childhood Dream: Movie Actor
description: Robert Tarango always idolized old-school leading men. Now he stars in a short film.
content: Doug Roland, a filmmaker, was walking home from a night out at 4 a.m. in the East Village when he saw a man standing on a deserted street corner in need of help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Why Closing Public Schools Is a ‘Last Resort’
description: The city’s schools will probably stay open because they double as social service centers for hundreds of thousands of poor students.
content: [Update: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has declared a state of emergency in New York over the coronavirus.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Beware the Deadly Contagion Spread by Blowhards
description: Ideology is getting in the way of science.
content: A virus can kill, of course, but so can blowhards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosemary Counter
title: There’s No Planning for Childbirth
description: Let go of your fantasy “birth story.”
content: Were I to travel a century back in time to meet my pregnant great-grandmother, I wonder how she might answer if I earnestly asked for her “birth plan.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Declaration Upon Walking In the Door
description: What would a women’s week be without Robyn Weintraub?
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I have really been savoring this week, solvers. I don’t mean to ruffle any genderfeathers; I just happen to extremely dig every one of the constructors we’ve seen so far. I am sure that you were all looking for this one yesterday, as Fridays are Robyn Weintraub’s domain, but have no fear: Here she is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: When Will We Be Ready for a President Warren?
description: Michelle Cottle joins readers in mourning the end of a dream for 2021.
content: “Winning the presidency is not merely — or even largely — a question of merit,” writes Michelle Cottle in her column, “Elizabeth Warren Had a Good Run. Maybe Next Time, Ladies.” “It’s hard for any candidate to get the formula right. For women, it is harder because of a host of unconscious biases.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Troy Collings, 33, Who Took Travelers Into North Korea, Dies
description: His company takes travelers to “destinations your mother would rather you stay away from.” One client was Otto Warmbier, who was imprisoned and fell into a coma.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — Troy Collings, whose tour-guide company specialized in taking young budget travelers to forbidding places like North Korea, where one of his clients, the American Otto F. Warmbier, was imprisoned and fell into a coma, died last week, the company said on Friday. He was 33.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Richard Fausset
title: The Mission to Hunt Nazis Has Become a Race Against Time
description: The latest target was a 94-year-old man in Tennessee said to have been a guard at a concentration camp in Germany. “These people are old, and they’re dying,” a prosecutor said of the cases’ urgency.
content: OAK RIDGE, Tenn. — It is perhaps fitting that the decades-long search for Nazi collaborators living on United States soil may have reached its conclusion — or something close to it — in a small city, in an unremarkable ranch house on an equally unremarkable cul-de-sac.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson Launches War on U.K.’s Own ‘Deep State’
description: A juicy boss-from-hell story illuminates the tensions between Britain’s radical new government and its solicitous but unyielding civil service.
content: LONDON — She is accused of flinging a folder at an aide, hitting the staffer in the head. She reportedly told another offending underling to “get out of my face” and castigated her staff as “useless,” adding an f-bomb for good measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Supporter of Gabriel Matzneff Says He Was Unaware of Pedophilia
description: Christophe Girard, a deputy mayor of Paris, disavowed years of association with the writer and said he learned only recently of the author’s abuses.
content: PARIS — A powerful deputy mayor of Paris, who has been criticized for his links to the pedophile writer Gabriel Matzneff, said on Friday that he had learned only recently of the author’s abuse of prepubescent boys and teenage girls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Ben Hubbard and Eric Schmitt
title: Roundup of Saudi Royals Expands With Detention of a 4th Prince
description: The arrests have raised questions about whether the crown prince was on the verge of taking full power from his father, King Salman.
content: The scope of a new roundup of Saudi royals widened on Saturday with word that a fourth senior prince has been detained under orders from Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, according to two Saudis close to the royal family, in a sign that he is determined to crack down on even whispers of dissent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Steve Weber, 76, a Founder of an Influential Folk Band, Dies
description: Mr. Weber and Peter Stampfel were the heart of the Holy Modal Rounders, a group born of the folk revival. It then detoured into a mischievous, “zany” style.
content: Steve Weber, the guitarist of the Holy Modal Rounders, a cult psychedelic folk group that grazed the pop-culture mainstream with a song featured in the 1969 film “Easy Rider” and influenced generations of underground musicians, died on Feb. 7 at his home in Mount Clare, W.Va. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Veterans Are Working, but Not in Jobs That Match Their Advanced Training
description: Like most Americans, veterans have benefited from a robust labor market. But skills learned in combat do not always translate to private-sector jobs.
content: Erica Uleski fought to save her fellow service members as an Army medic in Iraq, working under brutal conditions to stanch bleeding, save limbs and bring back lives teetering on the edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: A Sanders Voter, Weary of Debt at 29: ‘I Have Nothing to Lose’
description: Brian Michelz has never worn a political T-shirt or been to a campaign rally. But when he voted for the first time in his life, it was for Bernie Sanders. What will he do if Mr. Sanders loses?
content: MADISON, Wis. — Debt has dogged Brian Michelz his entire adult life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Sheri Fink and Noah Weiland
title: Inside Trump Administration, Debate Raged Over What to Tell Public
description: The administration’s response to the coronavirus has repeatedly matched public health experts against a hesitant White House, where worry of panic dominates.
content: WASHINGTON — After weeks of conflicting signals from the Trump administration about the coronavirus, the government’s top health officials decided late last month that when President Trump returned from a trip to India, they would tell him they had to be more blunt about the dangers of the outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and David Gelles
title: Boeing Faces $20 Million Fine by F.A.A.
description: The agency proposed the penalty over the installation of unapproved equipment in the 737 Max and other aircraft.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration recommended on Friday that Boeing be fined nearly $20 million for installing equipment in the 737 Max and other aircraft before its approval.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Ali Gascoigne pops over from across the pond with a cracker of a cryptic.
content: CRYPTIC — Now then, today we have a new-to-us setter, or cryptic constructor from England, the land of the ubiquitous cryptic puzzle. This isn’t quite Ali Gascoigne’s New York Times debut, as he constructed a Monday puzzle last February (perhaps you remember the debut of BRAINFOODS? It was a good puzzle). When that one came out, Deb Amlen interviewed Mr. Gascoigne and gleaned tidbits of knowledge like his day job (marketing strategist) and his cryptic nom de plume (Gila, a river and a poisonous lizard, and also Ali G in reverse).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Retiring Into a Shaky Market? Think Long Term Anyway
description: Americans in their mid-60s could live nearly three more decades, research shows, so a healthy dose of stock in your portfolio is actually prudent now.
content: If you’re on the cusp of retirement or have just stopped working, it’s hard to tune out the stock market’s recent gyrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: How I Tried to Ditch Africa’s Tropes
description: Guided by local residents, a correspondent discovered places full of poetry slams and restaurant birthday parties, art shows and surf contests, and mustardy grilled fish.
content: Dionne Searcey covered social, political and economic issues in 25 countries in West and Central Africa, with a focus on Nigeria’s war against Boko Haram, for four years for The New York Times. Now back in the United States, she reflects on how she challenged herself to go beyond bad news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: If Joe Biden Wins
description: A few things we’ll no longer have to worry about.
content: If Joe Biden wins the Democratic nomination, I’ll worry that his candidacy might be doomed. Doomed by Sanders supporters who, out of pique, will sit out the election; doomed by a throwback messenger with no particularly stirring message; doomed by hints of infirmity that many voters find worrisome and that Donald Trump will exploit with crass efficiency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mohammed Hanif
title: ‘How Do I Know Where Your Socks Are?’
description: “Warm up your own food!” Some things Pakistani women say make Pakistani men really angry.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — Last week, outside a shopping mall in the city, two somber men stood holding a banner that read: “Men are guardians of women.” In other parts of Pakistan, other self-appointed guardians have been busy tearing down posters that women activists put up to announce Aurat March, a series of rallies across the country to celebrate International Women’s Day on March 8.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart, Kate Kelly, Matt Phillips and Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Wall Street Had 2 Terrible Weeks. Here’s How 7 Traders Dealt With It.
description: As anxiety about coronavirus gave way to fear, investors dumped shares, watched the news and fielded client calls. “I have no energy left to speak.”
content: The past two weeks were among the worst in recent Wall Street history, as anxiety about the coronavirus outbreak gave way to alarm and drove panicked investors to sell their stock holdings, obliterating roughly $2 trillion in wealth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: There Won’t Be a Gay President in 2021. So What Does Buttigieg’s Campaign Tell Us?
description: Supporters say that Pete Buttigieg’s contribution to history will be diminished if the takeaway is that the country shrugged when the first openly gay man had a serious shot at the presidency.
content: It was the question that followed former Mayor Pete Buttigieg everywhere he went when he first announced his presidential campaign: Is the country really ready to send a gay man to the White House?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
title: A Quebec Ban on Religious Symbols Upends Lives and Careers
description: Four women recount how Quebec’s new secularism law has changed their lives.
content: MONTREAL — A Muslim lawyer who wears a head scarf has put aside her aspiration to become a public prosecutor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Vigilantes in Greece Say ‘No More’ to Migrants
description: Frustrated and exhausted by the lingering problems from the 2015 crisis, Greeks once generous with refugees are turning hostile, some violently.
content: EVROS, Greece — The farmers and pensioners wore black clothes and heavy boots, imitating Greece’s special forces, and trod along a rural road on a night patrol looking for migrants trying to cross the northern land border with Turkey. “We’ll get you next time!” they shouted at a small group of men who had made it over and fled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Kenny Atkinson Is Out as Nets Head Coach
description: Atkinson, who was in his fourth season, and the team “mutually agreed to part ways,” according to a statement on Saturday.
content: Kenny Atkinson will no longer be the head coach of the Nets after he and the team “mutually agreed to part ways,” the team abruptly announced on Saturday. Jacque Vaughn, an assistant, will serve as interim head coach for the rest of the season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: China May Be Beating the Coronavirus, at a Painful Cost
description: Beijing says its heavy-handed measures are working. Can other countries battling the outbreak learn from its efforts — or is the cure worse than the disease?
content: BEIJING — As the new coronavirus races around the world, tanking markets, cutting off global travel and suspending school for hundreds of millions of children, governments are desperate for ways to contain it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italy Locks Down Much of the Country’s North Over the Coronavirus
description: The restrictions affect Milan and the regions that serve as Italy’s economic engine, and are the most sweeping measures outside China.
content: ROME — Italy’s government early Sunday took the extraordinary step of locking down much of the country’s north, restricting movement for about a quarter of the Italian population in regions that serve as the country’s economic engine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Europe’s Coronavirus Outbreak Worsens, With Italy at Forefront
description: Italy’s government is taking the extraordinary step of locking down entire sections of the country’s north to fight the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Yesterday’ and ‘The Most Dangerous Animal of All’
description: A fantasy inspired by the music of the Beatles lands on HBO, and a true crime series from FX comes to Hulu.
content: YESTERDAY (2019) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. This Beatles-themed romantic comedy from the director Danny Boyle (“Trainspotting”) begins when Jack (Himesh Patel), a struggling singer-songwriter, gets hit by a bus during a mysterious global blackout. Suddenly — and with little explanation as to why — the Beatles have been wiped from history, and Jack is the only one who remembers them. So he does what any desperate artist would do. He performs and takes credit for their songs, becoming a rock star overnight. But a familiar lesson arises: Fame can’t buy love after all. The movie opened to mixed reviews last summer. Some critics said it’s best enjoyed if not taken too seriously, while others, like The New York Times’s A.O. Scott, said the plot could have dug deeper. “‘Yesterday’ is more of a novelty earworm than a classic,” he wrote. “It wasn’t made to last.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: No Cell Service. No Wi-Fi. Just Childhood.
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 7, 2020.
content: “Communication is a dying art because kids don’t talk. Ours do because there’s no alternative.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: SNC-Lavalin Is the Talk of Ottawa Again, if in a Very Different Context
description: Frustrations over a new light-rail system in the national capital built by a group that includes SNC-Lavalin have led to questions about a popular method for contracting big projects.
content: While Ottawa may be the national capital, the goings-on up on Parliament Hill aren’t what get most people here worked up these days. Instead, it’s the city’s new light-rail system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Conversations Toward Romance
description: The “just friends” zone ended after a year of talking and listening.
content: Shortly after Rachel Sutton texted Meredith Mechanik and asked her on a third date, Ms. Mechanik texted back and said she no longer wanted a romantic relationship with Ms. Sutton, and hoped instead that they could remain friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Tiger Woods Will Not Compete in Players Championship
description: “My back is simply just not ready for play next week,” Woods said in a Twitter post, raising concerns about his preparation for the Masters in April.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — Even after his stunning victory at last year’s Masters, Tiger Woods warned he would remain ever cautious with his surgically repaired back for the rest of his career. In that context, as Woods played only 12 tournaments in 2019, the decision was viewed as sensible and raised few eyebrows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Yesterday’ and ‘The Most Dangerous Animal of All’
description: A fantasy inspired by the music of the Beatles lands on HBO, and a true crime series from FX comes to Hulu.
content: YESTERDAY (2019) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. This Beatles-themed romantic comedy from the director Danny Boyle (“Trainspotting”) begins when Jack (Himesh Patel), a struggling singer-songwriter, gets hit by a bus during a mysterious global blackout. Suddenly — and with little explanation as to why — the Beatles have been wiped from history, and Jack is the only one who remembers them. So he does what any desperate artist would do. He performs and takes credit for their songs, becoming a rock star overnight. But a familiar lesson arises: Fame can’t buy love after all. The movie opened to mixed reviews last summer. Some critics said it’s best enjoyed if not taken too seriously, while others, like The New York Times’s A.O. Scott, said the plot could have dug deeper. “‘Yesterday’ is more of a novelty earworm than a classic,” he wrote. “It wasn’t made to last.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Case for Permanent Stimulus (Wonkish)
description: Check out our low, low interest rates.
content: If you’re a normal human being considering reading this post, fair warning: although it’s not super-technical, it’s aimed at a very wonky audience, and parts of it won’t exactly be in English. Also, it’s of limited policy relevance: the Trump administration would never consider the policy I suggest, and even a Biden administration would probably balk at going where I suggest. The only reason I’m writing about it is to get the idea out there. Oh, and I don’t think it’s very different from what Larry Summers has been saying, but I thought it might be helpful to put some stylized numbers to what I believe, and believe he believes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas, Sarah Kliff and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: With Test Kits in Short Supply, Health Officials Sound Alarms
description: Despite efforts by President Trump and others to reassure the public that tests are getting disseminated quickly, several states, doctors and patients complained that access was limited.
content: President Trump claimed again on Friday that anyone who needed a coronavirus test “gets a test.” But from Washington State to Florida to New York, doctors and patients are clamoring for tests that they say are in woefully short supply, and their frustration is mounting alongside the growing number of cases around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: The Market Is Rocky. Will Target-Date Funds Change Their Strategy?
description: Not much. That’s partly because they’re investing for the long term, and partly because they’re protecting you from your own worst instincts.
content: The professionals are in charge, and they may just protect you from yourself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Barr Increasingly Appears Focused on Undermining Mueller Inquiry
description: A judge’s criticism cast light on the first in a series of steps by the attorney general to take aim at the Russia investigation.
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr testified before Congress last spring that “it’s time for everybody to move on” from the special counsel investigation into whether Trump associates conspired with Russia’s 2016 election interference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich, James B. Stewart and Matt Phillips
title: Spiraling Virus Fears Are Causing Financial Carnage
description: A global disease outbreak isn’t the kind of risk that many investors were trained to react to.
content: There is nothing investors hate more than uncertainty. Right now, that is all there is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Junting Zhou
title: Self-Quarantined for the Holidays
description: I was stuck inside with my parents during Chinese New Year. Here’s what we did.
content: I was stuck inside with my parents during Chinese New Year. Here’s what we did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: As Weinstein Awaits Prison, Prosecutors Detail 40 Years of Accusations
description: Seeking a harsh sentence, Manhattan prosecutors argued that the once-powerful producer had “sexually violated many women.”
content: Manhattan prosecutors on Friday urged the judge who will sentence the once-powerful film producer Harvey Weinstein to consider what they said was a four-decade history of sexual assaults against women for which he had never been charged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Junting Zhou
title: Self-Quarantined for the Holidays
description: I was stuck inside with my parents during Chinese New Year. Here’s what we did.
content: I was stuck inside with my parents during Chinese New Year. Here’s what we did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Traub
title: Our ‘Pursuit of Happiness’ Is Killing the Planet
description: We need to strike a new balance between our private pleasures and our collective survival.
content: As the coronavirus continues to spread, the chances that any one of us will be placed in quarantine goes up considerably. I know that being locked away like that would drive me nuts. Two weeks subtracted from my life! Still, I’d accept the justice of my confinement because I would recognize that my liberty had come to pose a real danger to my fellow humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Gates
title: Melinda Gates: How to Start the Conversation About Gender Equality
description: A few minutes of your day could have an outsize impact on inequality.
content: The World Economic Forum recently projected that it will take 208 years to close major gender gaps in the United States — but this should only take a few minutes. Take a moment from your Sunday routine to join me in marking International Women’s Day in a small, but potentially important, way: Start a conversation about gender equality. Even better, talk about it with someone you’ve never discussed it with before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryce Covert
title: Where’s Joe Biden’s Universal Child Care Plan?
description: The issue is getting more attention than it has in decades, except from the Democratic front-runner.
content: In her parting remarks to her staff this week, Elizabeth Warren took a moment to talk about the lasting mark her candidacy had left on the race. “You know, a year ago, people weren’t talking about a two-cent wealth tax, universal child care, canceling student loan debt for 43 million Americans while reducing the racial wealth gap or breaking up big tech,” she said. “And now they are.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The Resurrection of Joe Biden
description: He’s alive, but he still needs some work.
content: Joe Biden’s presidential candidacy is back from the dead, in the sort of electoral turnaround that makes pundits’ heads explode. With the party’s moderate wing now coalescing behind him, Mr. Biden has suddenly gone from being gently ignored — like the dotty uncle who’s forever talking nonsense at family get-togethers — to being touted as the man to beat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Celine Tien
title: I’m Chinese. That Doesn’t Mean I Have Coronavirus.
description: “If you’re scared of me, get up and leave.”
content: LOS ANGELES — I turned 24 last month. The day before my birthday, I walked into a nail salon to get myself a birthday manicure. After I was seated, a nail technician walked over. She was an Asian woman in her 50s. She sat down and I smiled at her. I couldn’t see if she smiled back because she was wearing a face mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: How to Quarantine Yourself
description: Thousands who may have been exposed to the coronavirus have been asked to seclude themselves. It’s harder than it sounds.
content: Stay home unless you must see a doctor. No work, school or shopping. If you must come out of your room, wear a mask. And don’t share towels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Coronavirus Is Coming for Trump’s Presidency
description: Will a nationalist president be undone by his underreaction to a foreign threat?
content: On Jan. 31, over a month ago, the Trump administration made an excellent decision: In an effort to limit the spread of the coronavirus, it forbade most foreign nationals from entering the United States if they had recently traveled to China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Bernie Sanders Has Already Won the Democratic Primary
description: He set the tone, determined the issues and tugged the party toward him.
content: At a debate last month, Bernie Sanders’s rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination were asked if they were concerned about the party possibly graduating a democratic socialist to the general election. The only ones who made their worry perfectly clear were Joe Biden and Amy Klobuchar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Quoctrung Bui, Margot Sanger-Katz and Sarah Kliff
title: How Deadly Is Coronavirus? What We  Know and What We Don’t
description: The disease is still so new, and testing so limited, that the usual methods of analysis epidemiologists rely on are not yet viable.
content: The disease is still so new, and testing so limited, that the usual methods of analysis epidemiologists rely on are not yet viable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: N.C.A.A. Weighs Using Fewer March Madness Venues Amid Coronavirus Outbreak
description: With their marquee basketball tournaments looming, college sports officials have discussed whether they could — or should — play at fewer sites.
content: ATLANTA — Faced with the United States’ surging coronavirus caseload and mounting public fears, college sports executives have discussed in recent days whether to reduce the number of venues at which games are played during the N.C.A.A. men’s and women’s basketball tournaments that begin in less than two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Learning the Hard Way What It Means to Be a Top Pick for the Knicks
description: RJ Barrett is the latest in a long line of high-profile rookies who have tried to make it in New York. Current and former Knicks say he has what it takes.
content: Knicks rookie RJ Barrett was in the midst of one of the best games of his career and he was doing it at Madison Square Garden against the Houston Rockets, a potential finals team. The crowd ate up his creative finishes at the rim, including one late in the fourth quarter that sent the Garden into a playofflike frenzy of jumping and screaming fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti and Adam Goldman
title: Erik Prince Recruits Ex-Spies to Help Infiltrate Liberal Groups
description: Mr. Prince, a contractor close to the Trump administration, contacted veteran spies for operations by Project Veritas, the conservative group known for conducting stings on news organizations and other groups.
content: WASHINGTON — Erik Prince, the security contractor with close ties to the Trump administration, has in recent years helped recruit former American and British spies for secretive intelligence-gathering operations that included infiltrating Democratic congressional campaigns, labor organizations and other groups considered hostile to the Trump agenda, according to interviews and documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Their Campaign Jobs Just Dried Up. And on Venmo, the Drinks Are Flowing.
description: The race is over. The race to the bar is on.
content: When Senator Elizabeth Warren dropped out of the presidential race on Thursday, it was a devastating blow for her supporters and the 1,000-some staff members she had hired from coast to coast. But within hours, hundreds of alerts began popping up on their phones: emojis of whiskey pours, clinking champagne flutes, sloshing beer mugs, martinis and red wine glasses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Quoctrung Bui, Margot Sanger-Katz and Sarah Kliff
title: How Deadly Is Coronavirus? What We  Know and What We Don’t
description: The disease is still so new, and testing so limited, that the usual methods of analysis epidemiologists rely on are not yet viable.
content: The disease is still so new, and testing so limited, that the usual methods of analysis epidemiologists rely on are not yet viable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: What Should My Building Be Doing to Prevent Coronavirus?
description: For now, the New York City health department is developing more extensive guidance for property owners and managers, and advising them to clean more often and use disinfectant products.
content: Q: I live in a large Manhattan apartment building and I’m increasingly worried about the risk of contracting coronavirus in the lobby and other common areas. What should my building be doing to keep residents safe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Edgar Sandoval
title: Coronavirus in N.Y.: Cuomo Declares State of Emergency
description: The announcement came as the number of patients in New York rose to 89, including a Queens driver who worked for Uber.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo declared a state of emergency on Saturday as the number of coronavirus cases in New York rose to 89, which include a Queens driver who worked for Uber and two unexplained positive tests of patients 200 miles to the north.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Johnson
title: Coronavirus Closed This Starbucks, but Seattle Needs Its Coffee
description: “Seattle is freaking out,” one man said as he passed a Starbucks in downtown Seattle that was closed after an employee tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: SEATTLE — Machele Miely, on her way to meet a friend for coffee in downtown Seattle on Saturday, stopped to snap a photo on her phone of a sign posted on the door of a Starbucks saying that the store was temporarily closed and that it was sorry for the inconvenience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Marnie, Shih Tzu Who Charmed Instagram With Her Lolling Tongue, Dies at 18
description: At 12, she became an internet sensation and a poster dog for adopting older pets.
content: Marnie, the Shih Tzu whose lolling tongue, amused expression and tilted gait made her a celebrity on Instagram, died on Thursday at her Los Angeles home. She was 18.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Nada Rashwan
title: On Nile Cruiser, 12 Crew Test Positive for Virus, and Egypt Fears Broader Outbreak
description: The sudden surge of cases stoked growing fears among a nervous Egyptian public of a much larger number of infections than their government has either detected or declared.
content: CAIRO — Twelve crew members aboard a cruise ship on the Nile were placed in isolation on Friday after testing positive for the coronavirus, Egypt’s health ministry said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Matt Stevens
title: Biden Is Back: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. won South Carolina and most of the Super Tuesday states, and the race is down to him and Bernie Sanders, after Elizabeth Warren and Michael Bloomberg dropped out.
content: In just seven days, the Democratic race has changed almost beyond recognition. Let’s catch you up on the biggest week of the campaign so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Democratic Majority in Virginia Strips Itself of the Power to Draw District Lines
description: The State Legislature, controlled by Democrats, voted to put a constitutional amendment on the November ballot that would let an independent commission draw district maps.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats in Virginia’s State Legislature took a blue-moon political step on Friday and voted to largely strip themselves of the power to draw new political maps next year — maps that could well have locked them into power for a decade. But to say they acted grudgingly is an understatement.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 53 Ideas for Weekend Breakfasts
description: Pancakes, breakfast casseroles and more recipes.
content: Make a special breakfast with Ali Slagle’s recipe for huevos rotos (above); Alison Roman’s eggs Benedict; Mark Bittman’s recipe for everyday pancakes; and more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Karen Weise
title: Coronavirus Hits a Nursing Home and a Retirement Complex in Seattle Area
description: The facilities reported coronavirus cases among their residents on Friday, capping a week that included 10 deaths linked to another nursing home in the region.
content: SEATTLE — Days after a coronavirus outbreak emerged inside a nursing home in suburban Seattle, leaders at two other complexes that serve older residents in the region said on Friday that each of those facilities had a resident who had tested positive for the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Trump’s Crazy Fantasy World
description: In what The Spectator calls “the Year of the Drunken Uncle,” three old guys vie for the presidency amid coronavirus fears and a careering stock market.
content: WASHINGTON — The cruel insults to Joe Biden’s mental acuity are flying fast and ferocious on Fox News.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: For Urban Poor, the Coronavirus Complicates Existing Health Risks
description: An outbreak could devastate low-income black and Latino communities that, even in the best of times, face serious medical challenges.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Several days had passed since the congestion in her chest left her feeling suffocated and racing to the emergency room. Now, Lisa McClendon, 64, was trying to level with her respiratory therapist about why her asthma had flared up again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Konyndyk
title: Trump, His Eye on the Border, Overlooked the Coronavirus Threat
description: His insistence that the danger was overseas and could be kept out led officials to downplay the disease’s spread and the need for tests.
content: On Jan. 20, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found for the first time that the Covid-19 coronavirus had infected an American, a man from Snohomish County, Wash., who had returned from China five days earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa W. Foderaro
title: Let It Snow
description: Rain has replaced what used to be a white winter in my corner of the world.
content: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — It used to snow here. Not all the time. Not like Vermont or the Adirondacks in upstate New York, where it snows on and off all winter, barely registering a mention at the corner store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Lebanon Will Default on Foreign Debt Payment Amid Deepening Economic Crisis
description: The decision will appease protesters who have clamored for the government to prioritize domestic concerns. But it does little to solve the nation’s financial woes.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanon will default on $1.2 billion in foreign currency debts coming due on Monday, the prime minister said Saturday, as the country lurched deeper into an economic crisis that has set off widespread antigovernment protests and left the country grasping for a foreign bailout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Florida Woman Changed Voters’ Party Affiliations, Officials Say
description: Cheryl A. Hall falsified 10 registration forms, at least six of which enrolled Democratic and independent voters as Republicans, said the authorities, who are eyeing an additional 109 forms.
content: A Florida woman was charged on Thursday after officials said she filled out 10 voter registration forms with false information, at least six of which enrolled Democratic and independent voters in the Republican Party without their consent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: With No Braille Option, a Blind Man Failed His Citizenship Exam
description: Lucio Delgado said U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services did not deliver the Braille reading test he had requested. He may get another chance next week.
content: Lucio Delgado was excited when he went to the post office last month to pick up an envelope from U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services.
source.name: The New York Times
